Award.AwardTitle: SciLAF: Scientific-based Learning Assessment Framework for Student Knowledge Tracking

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal is addressing the fundamental challenge of assessing individual student's knowledge in cornerstone engineering classes with high student-to-faculty ratios. The goal is to: develop a computational assessment framework that easily integrates into an instructor's routine efforts to track student knowledge, suggest remedial interventions, and guide future examinations. The rationale is that individual student knowledge is a hypothesis/model that needs to be tested using the scientific method. Similarly, assessment instruments are just experiments to discover how well a student masters specific concepts. This fits naturally with probabilistic methodologies such as the Bayesian inference that formalize the scientific method.

The main approach taken is to track the progress of individual students by developing student knowledge models based on Bayesian networks. This proposal addresses an open fundamental problem in constructing and using knowledge models to assess learning, namely how to relate curricular structure to knowledge models and how to inform the models using assessment data. The proposed methodology emphasizes the role of concept inventories to inform the construction of Bayesian networks models and to extract information from these models to suggest informative questions for future examinations. To facilitate ease of use and broader adoption by faculty, the software artifacts will be made available under open source licenses and the functionality of the framework will be integrated within a widely used learning management system through the development of a prototype plugin. The education and outreach aspects of this proposal include training participants in effective educational strategies and mentoring of future faculty.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this proposal is to create a novel computational framework that easily integrates into instructors’ routine to track student knowledge in large classes of fundamental engineering courses. This knowledge assessment framework has an immediate positive impact on the learning outcomes of students through personalized feedback reports and can help instructors identify ill-designed questions and misconceptions.

The individualized competency reports are generated using the outputs of probabilistic models. As compared with grades that capture a quantitative assessment of a sum of concepts, our proposed models provide granular information with respect to student’s knowledge for each individual concept as well as the impact of not addressing the challenging concepts on the future plan of study.

In our surveys, we have found that the individualized competency reports generated using student model outputs are welcomed and actionable by the students. The main findings of our surveys are the followings: (1) The majority of the students read their individualized feedback reports, (2) The majority of the students had acted on the recommendations provided, (3) The majority of the students prefer to receive this type of formative feedback, (4) The majority of the students agree with the accuracy of the information provided in the email.

In addition to guiding the generation of individualized competency reports, we have found that the proposed student knowledge models can be used to identify misconceptions and evaluate the design of assessment instruments. This empowers instructors with the necessary tools to identify ill-designed questions, distractors, and misconceptions that students have to quickly intervene and make necessary changes in the material taught.

While currently the student models that we have created target only Statics, the tools and the methodology can be broadly applied to any discipline. We expect that the available open source codes and models generated by this research (https://bitbucket.org/uqlab/scilaf) will be adopted by other departments and colleges. The proposed methodology has been applied in the context of traditional classes, however, it has the potential to be extended to Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs), improving the learning outcomes and knowledge of a significantly broader audience than the traditional students.
